prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference
prior_works.role: Foundational framework for interventions and counterfactuals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s implementation of the do-operator and its abduction–action–prediction logic for interventional and counterfactual queries is grounded in Pearl’s structural causal model (SCM) formalism.

prior_works.title: A Linear Non-Gaussian Acyclic Model for Causal Discovery (LiNGAM)
prior_works.authors: Shohei Shimizu, Patrik O. Hoyer, Aapo Hyvärinen, Antti Kerminen
prior_works.role: ICA–causality link and identifiability in linear SCMs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: LiNGAM established the use of ICA ideas for identifying causal models from observations, which this work generalizes to nonlinear settings via nonlinear ICA and normalizing flows under a known causal ordering.

prior_works.title: Unsupervised Feature Extraction by Time-Contrastive Learning and Nonlinear ICA
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper leverages nonlinear ICA identifiability (e.g., through auxiliary/time structure) to argue that, given a causal ordering, the causal mechanisms are identifiable from observational data and thus recoverable with autoregressive flows.

prior_works.title: Variational Autoencoders and Nonlinear ICA: A Unifying Framework
prior_works.authors: Ilyes Khemakhem, Diederik P. Kingma, Ricardo Pio Monti, Aapo Hyvärinen
prior_works.role: Modern identifiability theory for nonlinear latent-variable models
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Identifiability conditions from iVAE provide the theoretical underpinning for recovering latent exogenous noises and structural functions, supporting the paper’s claim that causal NFs can identify SCMs from observations under mild side information (ordering).

prior_works.title: Masked Autoregressive Flow for Density Estimation
prior_works.authors: George Papamakarios, Theo Pavlakou, Iain Murray
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MAF supplies the triangular, autoregressive, invertible parameterization needed to align with a causal ordering, enabling recovery and likelihood-based training of causal mechanisms as flow components.

prior_works.title: Density Estimation Using Real NVP
prior_works.authors: Laurent Dinh, Jascha Sohl-Dickstein, Samy Bengio
prior_works.role: Practical invertible flows via coupling layers
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Real NVP popularized efficient, invertible parameterizations with tractable Jacobians, informing the design choices and practical training considerations for the paper’s causal normalizing flows.

prior_works.title: Deep Structural Causal Models for Tractable Counterfactual Inference
prior_works.authors: Nick Pawlowski, Sebastian Castro, Ben Glocker
prior_works.role: Precedent for using invertible neural networks for SCMs and counterfactuals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work showed how invertible networks can realize SCMs and enable abduction for counterfactuals, directly inspiring the paper’s systematic implementation of the do-operator and counterfactual reasoning with normalizing flows.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—casting structural causal models in the language of autoregressive normalizing flows, proving identifiability under a known causal ordering via nonlinear ICA, and operationalizing interventions and counterfactuals—emerges from two converging threads. First, the SCM formalism of Pearl provides the target semantics: interventions via the do-operator and counterfactuals via abduction–action–prediction. Second, the ICA–causality lineage (LiNGAM) established that causal discovery can be grounded in latent-source identifiability, a perspective extended to nonlinear settings through modern nonlinear ICA theory (Hyvärinen & Morioka) and its unifying identifiability results in iVAE. These results justify that, with an ordering, one can recover structural mechanisms from observational data.
On the modeling side, flow-based generative models—especially MAF’s triangular autoregressive parameterization and Real NVP’s efficient invertible couplings—supply practical, likelihood-trained, invertible mappings perfectly aligned with causal factorizations. This triangularity directly mirrors a causal ordering, enabling each node’s mechanism to be learned as a conditional flow with tractable Jacobians and sampling. Finally, prior work on deep structural causal models using invertible networks demonstrated that invertibility enables abduction of exogenous noise and thus tractable counterfactual inference, a capability the present paper systematizes for normalizing flows. Together, these works yield a principled and practical recipe: exploit nonlinear ICA identifiability to recover SCMs from observations, instantiate mechanisms as autoregressive flows consistent with a causal order, and implement interventions/counterfactuals by manipulating flow components in the SCM.
